misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that an array shift loop structured `for (int i = N - 1; i > 0; i--)` correctly handles copying *all* elements from index `i-1` to index `i` required for a full right shift of `N` elements, even though it stops when `i=1` (copying the element at index 0 to index 1).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The intended array right shift requires moving elements from `arr[i-1]` to `arr[i]` for all indices `i` from `N-1` down to 1, inclusive. The student's loop implements this correctly for `i > 0`. However, the identified issue is that this loop structure is standard for the shifting operation itself and doesn't inherently contain a conceptual flaw, but rather reinforces correct implementation of the shift part before the wrapping. Given the trace, the code executes the shift correctly up to index 1 (copying arr[0] to arr[1]). Since no actual logical error caused by stopping the loop too early or too late was observed (the implementation is standard for array shifting starting from the end down to `i=1`), we focus on the successful implementation of the specific shift mechanism employed.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None. This section of the code handles the shifting correctly.
